ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot of new vocabulary and grammar constructions, as well as a lot about Soviet history, and greatly improved my Russian comprehension and speaking skills.
I learned a lot about 20th century Soviet history through fun topics and great films. We learned useful vocabulary and used it in real world scenarios.
My Russian language ability improved a lot. I also learned about random subjects covered in class such as the "thaw" in Soviet-American relations and the climate situation.
I improved my speaking ability, especially improvisational speaking level.
I learnt so much new vocabulary that is relevant for the issues I am interested in!
I became much more confident in my speaking ability as well as developed my knowledge of Russian and Soviet social perspectives that previous Russian classes did not offer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This is an incredible class that teaches you a tremendous amount of Russian. The curriculum is very well thought out and interesting, and Irina Andreevna is an amazing professor. The only weakness would be that the homework assignments can sometimes be very long, which is a bit overwhelming if they are posted close to class time.

S: Love when we do group scenarios (ie Debates, conferences, business panels, interviews, etc). Irina helps us fill in the words we don't know why we get to practice. Also, the films for the class are a lot of fun. 
W: Homework could be a little disorganized, which can be stressful, but Irina is very good at quick feedback, and is very open to suggestions.

The strengths are that you speak a lot of Russian, and do a lot of Russian homework outside of class. The only weakness was that the class was disorganized. It was not always clear what homework had been assigned, what tests were about, etc.
No weaknesses. Strengths are the engaging material based on students' own interests.

The course's greatest strength is that the topics we cover can be customized based on the issues the cohort is interested in! If I could suggest one area of improvement, it would be that there could be more frequent quizzes - at least on a fortnightly basis or once in three weeks.

The strengths of this course are the flexibility and willingness of the professor to listen to students' interest and tailor content accordingly. The level of engagement and opportunities for debate and conversation were frequent and useful. 

The course could be improved by having more grammatical exercises for new topics. I also think an organization of homework by type (articles with questions, vocabulary, etc) could be found in separate documents. The only confusion I encountered while taking the course was that sometimes the homework assignments were found on one document.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Of course, Russian is the best department at Yale, bar none!
Yes, absolutely if you want to improve your Russian.
I think it's a great class if you're looking to get the certificate and explore some new areas of Russian culture.
Yes, I would, if you want to take a relatively rigorous high-level Russian course.
I love Irina and she is a wonderful Russian professor. She's so incredibly passionate about her students, the material, and helping the entire class improve.
I would highly recommend this class to students who wish to accelerate Russian speaking skills and engage in pop culture and other similar Russian content outside of class.
